docs.lead_paragraph: FOR expectant parents, the first glimpse of the baby in the womb with an ultrasound machine is among life's most thrilling moments. Until a few years ago, however, even the best ultrasound images left something to the imagination. They were two-dimensional, grainy and black-and-white. Now, the latest ultrasound equipment takes real-time, moving, three-dimensional pictures and adds color to them. Parents can marvel at how much their child resembles Aunt Alice months before Aunt Alice sees the resemblance for herself.

headline.main: A Somersault! Live From the Womb, a 3-D Performance

docs.abstract: Technology used in medical ultrasound machines described; latest equipment takes realistic, moving, three-dimensional pictures and adds color to them; improvements are largely result of quantum jumps in computer capabilities in recent years; diagrams; photos (M)
docs.snippet: FOR expectant parents, the first glimpse of the baby in the womb with an ultrasound machine is among life's most thrilling moments. Until a few years ago, however, even the best ultrasound images left something to the imagination. They were...

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Senate sharply divided over whether to restrict human cloning experiments, President Bush is inviting opponents of the research to the White House on Wednesday to rally support for legislation that would prohibit all types of human cloning, either for reproduction or medical research. Mr. Bush, whose opposition to cloning is well known, is not expected to make any new policy pronouncements. Rather, his speech, which an administration official said would call for ''biomedical research through more ethical means,'' is part of a carefully timed effort to win the Senate cloning fight.
docs.abstract: Pres Bush, with Senate sharply divided over whether to restrict human cloning experiments, invites opponents of research to White House to rally support for legislation that would prohibit all types of human cloning, either for reproduction or medical research (S)
